Short explanation: A generic designator of any form group, irrespective of the hierarchical level.
Closed part of a sonata, symphony, concerto, or other musical piece
It designates a formal unit below the movement level and  is composed of sections.

Blending binary and ternary components, it involves a modulation and cadential confirmation of a secondary key (first part)  as well as a transposition section (recapitulated 2nd theme in the tonic key; second part)
Alternation of refrain (invariably in the tonic key, or changing keys) and contrasting couplets

Six part structure: 1) opening ritornello for orchestra, 2) a solo section, 3) subordinate-key ritornello for orchestra, 4) solo section functioning as recapitulation, 6) closing ritornello for orchestra interrupted by solo cadenza
Structure without large-scale thematic repetition, potentially subdivided by caesurae and/or contrasting sections
AB or AA’
AB or AA’, with rhyming endings.
ABA’ structure, grouped such that a bipartite design emerges (also known as Minuet form).
Tripartite structure; if [A][BA’], it is referred to as “rounded binary”.
ABA; exact repetion of A without repeats.
ABC; tripartite structure with no repetitive relationships between the sections involved.
Sonata form without development section
Sonata form with second half merging development and recapitulation (typically lack of double return)
Ternary sonata form (i.e., with main theme recapitulation)
Rondo-sonata form / sonata-rondo form
Concerto sonata form
Generic designator of a larger-scale unit of a formal whole (e.g., exposition, development).
Two-part or continous form/type
4 modules: 1) link from exposition; 2) entry zone; 3) central-action zone; 4) retransition
Essential sonata closure and re-composition
Module or section after the recapitulation, framing the movement (as an after-the-end  function)
Module or section before the exposition, framing the movement (as a before-the-beginning function)
Typically short melodic element connecting two phrases or sections
Two-part structure, consisting of an antecendent (HC or IAC) and a consequent (concluded by PAC)

Two-part structure, consisting of a presentation (no cadence) and a continuation (concluded by a half or full cadence). The presentation in turn is made up  of two (less frequently one or three) basic ideas.
Antecedent + continuation
Antecedent + cadential progression
compound basic idea + continuation
compound basic idea + consequent
2-bar bi, 2-bar ci, ending with HC or IAC
Following a first thematic phrase, there is a restatement of bi, closing with ci on PAC.
Smallest formal unit of a theme (typically 2 bars in length)
Basic idea is enlarged; it consists of two distinct parts, featuring prolongational harmony (rather than ending with a cadence).
Smallest formal unit of a theme (typically 2 bars in length); is in (melodic and/or harmonic) contrast to a preceding basic idea.
An idea, different from the basic idea, initiating the continuation phrase of a sentence.
breaking melodic material and/or formal units into smaller chunks
Realizes a cadential progression at the end of a theme/phrase
First part of sentence, containts two bi’s (rarely one or three bi’s), but does no lead to no cadence.
Second part of sentence, leads to cadence at the end (HC, IAC or PAC), unless the theme is of the dissolving type
Establishes home key, presents primary melodic material, and/or introduces the instrumental apparatus. Also refer
Establishes home key, presents primary melodic material, may contain more than one → primary themes
Independent/new material or dissolving (primary based), move towards MC
leads to PAC in subordinate key and EEC
leads to PAC in subordinate key and EEC, may contain more than one theme
follows the EEC, new melodic material or primary theme based
This is the first theme occuring in a theme zone, whether the primary, the secondary or the closing theme zone.
This is the second theme occuring in a theme zone, whether the primary, the secondary or the closing theme zone.
type of form, part of concerto form
More specifically, in the classial style it concerns section between formal cadence and return of a new largeV or I in preparing the repeat of the exposition
material after the cadential arrival; after PAC → closing section / codetta, after HC → standing on V ; “Anhang” in historical terminology
closing section, various lenghts (single bar up to a larger phrase) →  post-cadential
framing function; follows structural limits of main material
the initial unit of a sequence
repeating the melodic/harmonic material by consistent transposition (either “real” or “tonal”)
structural close of exposition
structural close of whole sonata
Cadence ending with V-I, with V typically prepared by a predominant function and I supporting a ^1 in the soprano.
Cadence ending with V-I, with V typically prepared by a predominant function and I supporting a ^3 in the soprano.
Cadence ending on V, with V prepared either with a predominant function or a transitory I chord.
Cadential pattern in which the expected final tonic chord belongs to the subsequent group (rather than closing the phrase).
Cadential pattern in which the expected final tonic chord is replaced by another sonority (e.g., vi, IV6, or viio65/V).
(does not exist in the classical style)
framing function; precedes the structural limits of main material
transition module
solo section of a concerto
independent, higher density than verse
augmenting material; during establishment of function
symmetrical deviation; inserting musical material not belonging to either sides
gradually replacing characteristics with other itmes
module after the chorus and closes this specific cycle
gain energy for chorus module
part of development section; prepares for core of development
literal or varied
complete formal unit with a cadence at the end
lyric variant, containing narrativ context to chorus
